qas.question: Why was the carnival feast typically the last opportunity to eat well?

answers.text: food shortage at the end of the winter

qas.question: What was one limited to during the winter?
Why would all the remaining stores of lard, butter and meat left at vastenavond be eaten?

answers.text: it would soon start to rot and decay

qas.question: When would new food sources be available for those who survived the winter?

context: Traditionally a carnival feast was the last opportunity to eat well before the time of <a0_0>food shortage at the end of the winter<a0_0/> during which one was limited to <a1_0>the minimum necessary<a1_0/>. On what nowadays is called vastenavond (<a2_0>the days before fasting)<a2_0/> all the remaining winter stores of lard, butter and meat which were left would be eaten, for <a3_0>it would soon start to rot and decay<a3_0/>. The selected livestock had in fact already been slaughtered in November and the meat would be no longer preservable. All the food that had survived the winter had to be eaten to assure that everyone was fed enough to survive until the coming <a4_0>spring<a4_0/> would provide new food sources.
